This might be perfectly fine for you to say this is a good enough tradeoff. We had so many offers from ICOs. I guess we can do one more question. Here in the front, last question."}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"SM: Two more questions."}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"WP: Two more questions and then yeah."}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"Q: Thinking about bitcoin, price has done what price does over time. What parameters on network growth and user adoption do you find meaningful?"}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"WP: That's a difficult question. If you're going to focus on one metric, it's going to be manipulated. If you take transactions, they are up, but are transactions up because of users or because of spam? It's difficult to figure out real usage and what's inflated or manipulated statistics."}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"FP: I tend to focus on developer metrics. The number of new developers working on bitcoin. It's not just bitcoin which is all software, but also wallets and lightning and things like that. The thing that is very telling for me is that I am more interested in ....."}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"WP: It's reconnecting."}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"SM: I'll answer while he's reconnecting. I think value transacted per second is an interesting measurement that people don't talk about. A lot of people talk about transaction volume or transactions per second. But that doesn't matter in a settlement network. You have to wait for confirmations and settlement. A year ago, bitcoin is the only network that moves thousands of dollars per second. It doesn't matter if a coin has a million transactions per second if it's worthless, because you're still not really moving money or value around and letting people transfer value. For bitcoin, 20% of a block, 10-15% are omni transactions... there's a lot of garbage transactions. You have to look at what's actually valuable. A media outlet criticized liquid. It said not a lot of transactions so not a lot of adoption."}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"WP: You have to check with a merchant like bitrefill."}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"SM: You can do the math yourself. How much money is being moved in a day?"}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"WP: Riccardo, you were talking before you started echoing?"}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"FP: Yeah, the only thing I want to say about developer metrics is that they can be gamed quite easily. I'm cautious about it. But if you take a look at Bitcoin Core in particular, Bitcoin pull requests are not merged rapidly. It's not developer metrics like the number of new lines of code that are merged, it's more like are people being attracted to work on the ecosystem as developers. I find that -- is very top-down."}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"SM: Does that answer your question?"}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"CL: People were asking, which metric to look at to see if bitcoin should be valued at a certain price. I think about it as another way. The price is a really good metric. The market cap of bitcoin is a metric of how successful it is. If it's a store of value, then the amount of money stored in bitcoin is how much people are willing to put their wealth in bitcoin and keep it there because that's the asset class they want to store the value in. Market cap is the best metric for how successful bitcoin is. But it's weird because people are trying to figure out what the market cap is."}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"SM: The problem with market cap is all the altcoins with inflated market caps."}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"CL: Well, liquidity also matters. It's market cap and liquidity."}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"WP: So it's a combination of things."}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"SM: I think it's safe to look at market cap for bitcoin, but not other things. Next and last question?"}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"Q: Have any of you had a chance to review the flood XMR paper?"}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"SM: That's a Riccardo question."}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"FP: Yes."}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"CL: He said yes."}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"Q: Can you talk about the ramifications?"}, {"type":"paragraph","text":"FP: Sure. The flood XMR paper is an extension of an attack that the Monero Research Lab detailed in their first paper in 2014 which basically says, if you own like 70-80% of the outputs on the network then you will be able to figure out with reasonable odds of certainty which is the true side of the ring signature. The problem with flood XMR is that they made a bunch of assumptions and they said it's trivial to own transactions on the network because outputs are super cheap, so you can create billions of outputs. They had a bunch of things wrong. The entire hypothesis was based on creating transactions with 100 outputs. But monero limits outputs to 16 outputs."}

FP: Well, whalepanda.

WP: We have two runners and two mics if anyone wants to ask questions. Please don't ask about liquid or anything else.

SM: You can ask about liquid.

CL: Ask us anything.

SM: We're doing Q&A because we didn't really plan a show.

Q: What's your best price pump theory for the recent price pump? Let's hear your theories. Let's hear your thoughts on your theory for the recent price pump.

WP: So, why did the price pump?

FP: The binance hacker wanted more money in the hot wallet, so he pumped the price. He needed more money in the hot wallet for him to steal.

WP: We brought a bull today, so tomorrow we will sacrifice the bull and then afterwards we will have a big barbeque. It was Novak's idea actually. The price went up because there's more demand.

WP: It's reconnecting.

SM: I'll answer while he's reconnecting. I think value transacted per second is an interesting measurement that people don't talk about. A lot of people talk about transaction volume or transactions per second. But that doesn't matter in a settlement network. You have to wait for confirmations and settlement. A year ago, bitcoin is the only network that moves thousands of dollars per second. It doesn't matter if a coin has a million transactions per second if it's worthless, because you're still not really moving money or value around and letting people transfer value. For bitcoin, 20% of a block, 10-15% are omni transactions... there's a lot of garbage transactions. You have to look at what's actually valuable. A media outlet criticized liquid. It said not a lot of transactions so not a lot of adoption.

It's not developer metrics like the number of new lines of code that are merged, it's more like are people being attracted to work on the ecosystem as developers. I find that -- is very top-down.

The market cap of bitcoin is a metric of how successful it is. Market cap is the best metric for how successful bitcoin is. But it's weird because people are trying to figure out what the market cap is.

SM: The problem with market cap is all the altcoins with inflated market caps.

CL: Well, liquidity also matters. It's market cap and liquidity.

WP: So it's a combination of things.

Q: Have any of you had a chance to review the flood XMR paper?

SM: That's a Riccardo question.

FP: Yes.

CL: He said yes.

Q: Can you talk about the ramifications?

FP: Sure. The flood XMR paper is an extension of an attack that the Monero Research Lab detailed in their first paper in 2014 which basically says, if you own like 70-80% of the outputs on the network then you will be able to figure out with reasonable odds of certainty which is the true side of the ring signature. The problem with flood XMR is that they made a bunch of assumptions and they said it's trivial to own transactions on the network because outputs are super cheap, so you can create billions of outputs. They had a bunch of things wrong. The entire hypothesis was based on creating transactions with 100 outputs. But monero limits outputs to 16 outputs.
summary:
In a recent engaging panel discussion, the conversation kicked off with a clarification regarding video content that was misinterpreted by some viewers as an attempt to discredit Craig Wright. The panelists clarified their stance, emphasizing that the focus of their content was on a broader range of topics and firmly established Wright's non-fraudulent status, distancing themselves from controversy and setting a respectful tone for the dialogue that followed.

The discussion then transitioned into the realm of merchandise, particularly focusing on exclusive coins that were designed for conference attendees. These limited edition items were highlighted not just for their scarcity but also for their potential future value, blending collectability with speculative investment. However, the panelists showcased a pragmatic approach by revealing plans to destroy any unsold merchandise to maintain its exclusivity, underscoring a commitment to value over volume.

A significant portion of the conversation illuminated the achievements and ambitions of Pixelmatic, a gaming company at the forefront of developing an MMORTS sci-fi space game. This project, drawing investments and talent from industry veterans, exemplifies the innovative intersection of gaming and blockchain technology. The venture’s progress highlights the potential of novel funding models through security tokens and cryptocurrency integration within games, showcasing a forward-thinking approach to game development and financing.

On market dynamics, insights were shared about the recent fluctuations in the cryptocurrency market, with various theories proposed to explain these movements. From external influences like hack attempts to intrinsic factors such as Bitcoin's 'halvening' event, the discussion underscored the speculative nature of cryptocurrency markets and the inherent challenges in making accurate predictions, enriching the audience’s understanding of market complexities.

Technical questions from the audience brought to light discussions on blockchain interoperability and the development hurdles faced by altcoins like Litecoin. An emphasis was placed on leveraging Bitcoin's advancements for Litecoin's benefit, illustrating the collaborative and symbiotic relationships between different blockchain projects and highlighting the communal ethos within the blockchain community.

An intriguing segment of the conversation critiqued current implementations of blockchain in gaming while proposing more nuanced approaches that could enhance game economies without straining the blockchain infrastructure. This discussion pointed toward the revolutionary potential of cryptocurrencies in redefining digital ownership and transactions within online games, suggesting a bright future for blockchain in the gaming industry.

Further technical inquiries led to discussions on cross-chain atomic swaps and their significance for privacy-focused cryptocurrencies like Monero, underscoring ongoing efforts to enhance interoperability and privacy within the cryptocurrency ecosystem. This demonstrated a deep dive into the technical aspects shaping the future of cryptocurrencies and their underlying technologies.

Throughout this diverse conversation, the panelists offered a comprehensive overview of current trends, challenges, and opportunities within the rapidly evolving digital landscape, spanning tangible aspects of cryptocurrency-related merchandise to technological advancements in blockchain and gaming. The dialogue seamlessly wove together clarifications, insights, and forward-looking discussions, providing listeners with a well-rounded perspective on the dynamic world of cryptocurrencies and blockchain technology.
